str2: A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Trustworthy, faithful, believing. From peitho; objectively, trustworthy; subjectively, trustful.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: (a) I wake, arouse, (b) I raise up. Probably akin to the base of agora; to waken, i.e. Rouse.
From out, out from among, from, suggesting from the interior outwards. A primary preposition denoting origin, from, out.
(a) adj: dead, lifeless, subject to death, mortal, (b) noun: a dead body, a corpse. From an apparently primary nekus; dead.
And, even, also, namely.
From the base of dokeo; glory, in a wide application.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
So that, therefore, so then, so as to. From hos and te; so too, i.e. Thus therefore.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
Faith, belief, trust, confidence; fidelity, faithfulness.
And, even, also, namely.
Hope, expectation, trust, confidence. From a primary elpo; expectation or confidence.
I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
